title: ICE: coherence failed to report ambiguity: cannot locate the impl of the trait

labels.name: I-ICE
labels.description: Issue: The compiler panicked, giving an Internal Compilation Error (ICE) ❄️

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
ICE resulting from insufficiently specified/unknown types and nested matching.

I tried this code:

``` rust
let (printSend, printRec) = channel();

let printer = thread::spawn(move || {
    loop {
        match printRec.recv() {
            Ok(file) => {
                match file {
                    Some(f) => println!("{}", f),
                    None => {}
                }
            },
            Err(_) => break
        }
    }
});
```

I expected to see this happen: Without any additional context, this code should result in a compile error since the type returned by `printRec.recv()` is not explicitly or implicitly available at the `println!` call.

Instead, this happened: The exact ICE returned by the compiler is

```
src/main.rs:62:16: 62:29 error: internal compiler error: coherence failed to report ambiguity: cannot locate the impl of the trait `core::marker::Send` for the type `[closure src/main.rs:62:35: 74:3]`
src/main.rs:62  let printer = thread::spawn(move || {
                              ^~~~~~~~~~~~~
```
## Meta

Here are my compiler versions from Linux, but it's good to note that compiling the same code on Windows gives the exact same error.

```
rustc 1.1.0 (35ceea399 2015-06-19)
binary: rustc
commit-hash: 35ceea3997c79a3b7562e89b462ab76af5b86b22
commit-date: 2015-06-19
host: x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu
release: 1.1.0
```

Backtrace:

